entry.title: Your Expert Guide to Mastering Copying Control in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Sales
entry.content:
Have you ever wondered about the "magic" that happens when you create a billing document from a preceding business document? How does the system know exactly which partner information, which items, and which pricing conditions to transfer? It’s not magic, it's copying control. 
 
For many who are familiar with SAP ECC or SAP S/4HANA (on premise), copying control is a powerful but complex area. In the public cloud, we've streamlined this process to align with our "fit-to-standard" philosophy, ensuring your system remains stable, secure, and always on the latest release. 
 
In this post, I'll demystify copying control in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. We'll cover what it is, how to configure it, and most importantly, how to work effectively within the cloud-native framework. 
 
What is Copying Control? The 'Why' Behind the Document Flow 
 
At its core, Copying Control is the rulebook that governs how data is transferred from a source document to a target document. It dictates the flow of business processes, such as: 
 
* Quotation -> Sales Order 
* Sales Order -> Outbound Delivery 
* Sales Order -> Billing Document 
* Delivery -> Billing Document 
 
This rulebook ensures data consistency, reduces manual entry, prevents errors, and automates your core business scenarios. 
 
The Building Blocks: Configuration Activities in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 
 
In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you'll manage these settings through configuration activities within the Central Business Configuration (CBC) environment or Manage Your Solution app. Here are the primary configuration activities for Sales, including Sales Billing: 

  • Define Copying Control for Sales Document to Billing Document (configuration activity ID 102762) 
  • Define Copying Control for Delivery Document to Billing Document (configuration activity ID 102763) 
  • Define Copying Control for Billing Document to Billing Document (configuration activity ID 102764) 
  • Set Copying Control: Sales Document to Sales Document (configuration activity ID 102905) 
  • Set Copying Control: Billing Document to Sales Document (configuration activity ID 102906) 
  • Define Data Transfer and Copying Rqmts for Sales Document (configuration activity ID 103089) 

The Golden Rule of Public Cloud: Checking Supported Combinations 

This is the most critical concept to grasp in the public cloud. Unlike on-premise systems, where you could create almost any combination, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition operates on a pre-defined, best-practice set of document flows. 
 
Before you attempt any configuration, you must verify that your desired document flow (e.g., from a sales document type to a billing type) is supported by SAP. 
 
How to Check Supported Combinations: 
 
The single source of truth is the SAP Signavio Process Navigator (formerly known as the SAP Best Practices Explorer). 
 
1. Navigate to the SAP Signavio Process Navigator  
2. Select the solution SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 
3. Find the relevant scope item for your process (e.g., BD9 - Sell from Stock). 
4. Examine the process flow diagram. This visual chart shows the standard, SAP-supported document flows. 
5. For detailed proof, review the test scripts associated with the scope item. They explicitly list the document types used in the standard process. For example - process flow diagram of BD9:

If your desired flow isn't documented there, it is not part of the SAP standard and likely won't work. 
 
A Deep Dive into Configuration: Header and Item
 
Let's break down the settings you'll find within the configuration activities. Configuration is typically managed at three levels: 
 
1. Header Level: This controls the general transfer of header data. 

* Data Transfer Routines: Pre-defined ABAP routines that copy data from the source header to the target header (e.g., `001` for general header data). In the cloud, you can only select from a fixed list of SAP-delivered routines. 


* Copying Requirements: Routines that check if a document is eligible for copying at the header level. For example, a requirement might check if the source document has an overall "complete" status. Again, you select from a pre-delivered list. 

 


2. Item Level: This provides granular control for each line item. 

* Data Transfer Routines: Similar to the header, these routines copy data at the item level (e.g., material, plant). 

* Copying Requirements: Checks conditions at the item level. A classic example is a routine that prevents a quotation item from being copied to an order if it has a "reason for rejection." 

* Update Document Flow: This crucial checkbox ensures that the relationship between the source and target document is recorded, allowing you to see the entire process chain in the document flow. 

* Pricing Type: Determines how pricing is handled in the target document. Common options include: 

* `B`: Carry out new pricing. 
* `C`: Copy manual pricing elements and redetermine others. 
* `D`: Copy pricing elements unchanged. 

* Copy Quantity: Specifies how the quantity is copied to the target document. 

The Public Cloud Paradigm: Limitations and Their Purpose 
 
This is where the "Cloud Mindset" comes in. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you will find certain limitations compared to an on-premise system, and they exist for very good reasons. 
 
Key Limitation: You cannot create custom ABAP routines for Data Transfer or Copying Requirements (known as VOFM routines in the on-premise world). You can only select from the dropdown list of routines provided by SAP. 
 
Why do these limitations exist? 
 
* Guaranteed Upgradability: Your system is upgraded automatically twice a year. By eliminating custom code at this deep level, SAP ensures that these upgrades are smooth, fast, and don't break your core processes. 

* Standardization and Stability: Using a pre-tested, pre-optimized set of routines guarantees system stability and performance for all customers on the public cloud platform. 

* Lower Total Cost of Ownership (TCO): You no longer need a team of developers to create, test, and maintain complex custom copying logic. This frees up your resources to focus on innovation. 
 
Workarounds and Cloud-Native Solutions 
 
So, what do you do if the standard routines don't meet a specific business need? You embrace cloud-native extensibility. 
 
1. Challenge the Process: First, ask "why?" Does the business process really need this unique logic, or can it adapt to the best-practice standard provided by SAP? Adopting the standard is always the most efficient path. 
 
2. Leverage Cloud BAdIs: For valid requirements, the modern solution is to use Business Add-Ins (BAdIs). Using the Custom Fields and Logic app, you can implement your own business logic at specific, pre-defined enhancement spots. 

* For example, a BAdI like `SD_BIL_DATA_TRANSFER` (Data Transfer for Billing Process Documents) could be used to fill a custom header or item field in a new billing document based on specific logic, achieving what a custom data transfer routine used to do. 

* This is the "clean core" approach. Your custom logic is kept separate from the standard SAP code, ensuring it doesn't interfere with upgrades. 
 
3. Utilize SAP-Delivered Routines Creatively: Explore the full list of provided routines. Sometimes, a combination of standard settings can achieve the desired outcome without any custom development. 
 
Conclusion 
 
Copying Control in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is powerful, but it requires a shift in mindset. It's less about building everything from scratch and more about understanding and leveraging a robust, standardized framework. 
 
Your key takeaways should be: 
 
* Always validate your desired document flow in the SAP Signavio Process Navigator first. 

* Embrace the standard. The pre-configured SAP Best Practices cover the vast majority of business needs. 

* When extensibility is required, use cloud-native tools like the Custom Fields and Logic app to implement BAdIs. 
 
By following these principles, you can build efficient and resilient business processes that are perfectly aligned with the strengths of the public cloud. 

For more in-depth information, some recommended official resources:

  • Copying Control in Sales Billing
  • Custom Data Transfer for Billing Process Documents
  • Custom Logic: Data Transfer and Copying Requirements for Sales Documents

If you have more questions, the SAP Community is a fantastic place to ask them. Happy configuring!

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud – Leveraging SAP Databricks’ assistant to easily build predictive scenarios
entry.content:
SAP Databricks provides a convenient way to accelerate the creation and delivery of predictive scenarios on top of SAP Business Data Cloud Data Products. The Databricks Assistant feature allows you to easily generate code to access SAP Data Products, apply the necessary data transformation steps to prepare the data, and execute predictive algorithms to produce insightful results. These results can then be materialized as a table, which you can be used in subsequent analytical scenarios.

 

  • Use Case: Forecasting Product Sales with S/4 Sales Orders Data
  • Step 1 – Selecting and Sharing a Data Product
  • Step 2 – Creating a Databricks Notebook
  • Step 3 – Retrieving the Data to Work On
  • Step 4 – Selecting and Transforming Data for Forecasting
  • Step 5 - Forecasting Sales Amounts and Product Quantities
  • Step 6 – Generating and visualizing final results
  • Step 7 - Create Product_Forecast table to save forecasted results
  • Useful Links

 

Use Case: Forecasting Product Sales with S/4 Sales Orders Data

To demonstrate how the Databricks assistant can be applied to a predictive use case—even without deep expertise in Databricks—we will leverage a SAP Business Data Cloud Data Product that enables us to retrieve sales order data from our S/4 system.

 

Step 1 – Selecting and Sharing a Data Product

From the Business Data Cloud Cockpit, we navigate to Catalog & Marketplace, filter the content type to Data Products using the list box, and search for sales order. The Sales Order Data Product then appears in the results.

Once we locate the Data Product, we verify that it is Active, which indicates that it has already been installed.

The Sales Order Data Product is marked as Active because the status appears in the lower-left corner of the displayed card.

“Sales Order” Data product Overview Tab

We can now proceed to the next step, which involves sharing the Data Product with the Databricks instance.

To do this, we select the Share button (located near the top-right corner of the Sales Order tab). This opens a window where we can choose the Databricks instance to use, define the Shared Name (i.e., the catalog name that will appear in Databricks), and specify the Databricks workspace to which the data tables will be shared via Delta Share technology.

Note: Delta Share is a secure data-sharing platform that enables you to share data without moving or replicating it—the data remains in place while being made accessible to authorized consumers.

Sharing a Data Product with Databricks

Once the Data Product is shared, a new catalog named salesorder appears in the Databricks Delta Shares Received folder.

Within this folder, you can see the two shared tables: salesorder and salesorderitem.

Databricks Catalog

 

Step 2 – Creating a Databricks Notebook

Databricks uses the Notebook concept as the primary tool for creating data science and machine learning workflows on Databricks. Databricks notebooks provide real-time coauthoring in multiple languages, automatic versioning, and built-in data visualizations for developing code and presenting results.

From Databricks, select the Create button and then choose Notebook.

Create Notebook

You now have a workspace where you can begin working. You may rename it to any name you prefer.

Notebook window

 

Step 3 – Retrieving the Data to Work On

We now need to select the columns from the SalesOrder and SalesOrderItem tables provided through Delta Share. These columns correspond to the material products that will be used to forecast the OrderQuantity and NetAmount measures.

To do this, move your mouse pointer inside the notebook within the first section. An action line will appear, allowing you to select the Assistant icon (the pink diamond).

Selecting Assistant icon

The Assistant window appears:

Databricks Assistant Window

We then type the following text into the Assistant window to generate the code:

 

Select columns salesorder, salesorderdate, salesorganization, SalesOrderType, 
DistributionChannel, OrganizationDivision, SoldToParty from salesorder.SalesOrder table 
and SalesOrderItem, Material, NetAmount, OrderQuantity, OrderQuantityUnit from SalesOrder.SalerorderItem table 
for Material products 'HEADPHONE', 'CP1-FG-100', 'DBS-1002', 'CH-6010' 
where salesorder.SalesOrder = SalesorderItem.SalesOrder

 

After selecting the Generate button, the assistant produces the following code snippet:

Note: The exact code may vary depending on the context, but it will perform the same operation—retrieving the relevant columns data from the SalesOrder and SalesOrderItem tables. 

Click Accept. Then, click Run Cell to execute the code and retrieve the data from the SalesOrder and SalesOrderItem tables.

 

After processing, the results appear as a table in your notebook. This table displays the selected columns from the SalesOrder and SalesOrderItem tables, ready to be used. The resulting table  is stored in df object so you can reuse it in the following steps.

Step 4 – Selecting and Transforming Data for Forecasting

Now that we have the raw data, we need to transform it into the dataset required for our predictive forecasting scenario.

The generated table (i.e. df) will be used to forecast OrderQuantity and NetAmount by Material. To prepare the dataset:

  • Aggregate OrderQuantity and NetAmount by Year-Month

  • Ensure the month is displayed with two digits (e.g., 01, 02, ... , 12) so that values can be sorted correctly

  • Retain additional relevant columns to provide context for the forecasting process

This transformation step ensures the dataset is structured and ready for accurate forecasting analysis.

We will use the assistant to generate the transformations:

To do this, move your mouse pointer inside the notebook just under the  previous table. An action line will appear, allowing you to select the Assistant icon (the pink diamond).

Selecting Assistant icon

The Assistant window appears:

Databricks Assistant Window

We then type the following text into the Assistant window to generate the code:

 

Use df as a table to generate a new table 
where rows aggregate with SUM orderquantity , Netamount by Date 
where date is the concatenation of Year "-" Month with month in 2 digits
and keeping the following columns data SalesOrganization, SalesOrderType, DistributionChannel, OrganizationDivision, 
SoldToParty, SalesOrderItem, Material, NetAmount, OrderQuantity, OrderQuantityUnit
You'll get the text in the assistant window 

Assistant window with request

You can now generate the code by pressing Generate button. Generated code

Once accepted, you can run the code and obtain the resulting table with the requested results. The results are stored in agg_df object for further reuse.

Table Results

To better visualize the result and check if you got what you wanted, you can create a visualization.

To do so, select the “+” tab near the “Table” tab and select “Visualization”

Create Visualization

 

You’ll see appear the Visualization editor pane:

VIsualization Editor Properties

 

Select the following parameters values:

              Visualization Type: Line

              X Column: Date

              Y Column: OrderQuantity

             Group By: material

 

The visualization is displayed dynamically.

Visualization Editor

 Click on Save to save the chart.

By displaying the visualization you can check that results are what you wanted and start identifying some patterns that you may want to find again in the forecasted numbers.

 

Step 5 - Forecasting Sales Amounts and Product Quantities

Now that the dataset has been prepared, we can begin the predictive process by generating forecasts.

In this step, the transformed table (agg_df) will be used to forecast both OrderQuantity and NetAmount by Material. The forecasting process leverages the aggregated Year-Month values to identify trends and predict future sales amounts and product quantities.

This step marks the transition from data preparation to predictive analytics, where the insights derived from the forecasts can support decision-making and planning.

5.1 Installing the Predictive library

To generate forecasts, we first need to install the Prophet predictive library.

  1. Move your mouse pointer beneath the previous section until the action line appears.

  2. Select the Assistant icon (the pink diamond).

  3. In the Assistant window, type the following request to install Prophet:

 

Install Prophet library to create predictive model

 Click Generate and you’ll get the following code generated

Run generated code to install the Prophet library by clicking on "Run Cell"

5.2 Requesting the Forecast with Prophet Library

Once the Prophet library has been installed, we can request what to forecast and how to perform the prediction.

  1. Move your mouse pointer beneath the previous section until the action line appears.

  2. Select the Assistant icon (the pink diamond).

  3. In the Assistant window, type the following instruction to generate the forecasting code:

 

Use Prophet library and Use df_agg 
to forecast OrderQuantity and OrderNetAmount by Material as integer from df_agg
by Date for next 12 months from 2025-10 to 2026-10 ,
put forecasted values in OrderQuantityForecast and NetAmountForecast columns 
and add 4 columns OrderQuantityForecastMax OrderQuantityForecastMin NetAmmountForecastMax and NetAmountForecastMin 
to put max OrderQuantity and NetAmount forecasted values and min forecasted value
 

Click Generate to get the following code:

 

import pandas as pd
from prophet import Prophet

pdf = df_agg.toPandas()
pdf['Date'] = pd.to_datetime(pdf['Date'], format='%Y-%m')
future_dates = pd.date_range(start='2025-10-01', end='2026-10-01', freq='MS')

forecast_results = []

for material, group in pdf.groupby('material'):
    # Forecast OrderQuantity
    df_q = group[['Date', 'OrderQuantity']].rename(columns={'Date': 'ds', 'OrderQuantity': 'y'})
    m_q = Prophet()
    m_q.fit(df_q)
    future_q = pd.DataFrame({'ds': future_dates})
    forecast_q = m_q.predict(future_q)
    forecast_q['OrderQuantityForecast'] = forecast_q['yhat'].round().astype(int)
    forecast_q['OrderQuantityForecastMax'] = forecast_q['yhat_upper'].round().astype(int)
    forecast_q['OrderQuantityForecastMin'] = forecast_q['yhat_lower'].round().astype(int)

    # Forecast NetAmount
    df_n = group[['Date', 'NetAmount']].rename(columns={'Date': 'ds', 'NetAmount': 'y'})
    m_n = Prophet()
    m_n.fit(df_n)
    future_n = pd.DataFrame({'ds': future_dates})
    forecast_n = m_n.predict(future_n)
    forecast_q['NetAmountForecast'] = forecast_n['yhat'].round().astype(int)
    forecast_q['NetAmountForecastMax'] = forecast_n['yhat_upper'].round().astype(int)
    forecast_q['NetAmountForecastMin'] = forecast_n['yhat_lower'].round().astype(int)

    # Add static columns from group
    static_cols = group.iloc[0][[
        'salesorganization', 'salesordertype', 'distributionchannel',
        'organizationdivision', 'soldtoparty', 'salesorderitem', 'material', 'orderquantityunit'
    ]]
    for col in static_cols.index:
        forecast_q[col] = static_cols[col]

    forecast_q['Date'] = forecast_q['ds'].dt.strftime('%Y-%m')
    forecast_results.append(forecast_q[[
        'Date', 'salesorganization', 'salesordertype', 'distributionchannel',
        'organizationdivision', 'soldtoparty', 'salesorderitem', 'material',
        'NetAmountForecast', 'NetAmountForecastMax', 'NetAmountForecastMin',
        'OrderQuantityForecast', 'OrderQuantityForecastMax', 'OrderQuantityForecastMin',
        'orderquantityunit'
    ]])

forecast_df = pd.concat(forecast_results, ignore_index=True)
forecast_spark = spark.createDataFrame(forecast_df)
display(forecast_spark)
Click Run Cell to run the code

 

Forecasted results appear in the new table and results are stored in forecast_spark object.

 

Step 5.3 – Creating a Visualization of the Forecast

To better understand the results and confirm that the forecast meets expectations, you can create a visualization.

5.3.1 Creating a Visualization for OrderQuantity Forecast

  1. Select the “+” tab next to the Table tab.

  2. Choose Visualization.

  3. The Visualization Editor pane will appear.

  4. Configure the parameters as follows:

Visualization Type: Line

Column: Date

Y Column: OrderQuantityForecast

Y Column: OrderQuantityForecastMax

Y Column: OrderQuantityForecastMin

Group By: Material

Once applied, you should see a line chart displaying the forecasted OrderQuantity values, along with the maximum and minimum forecast ranges, grouped by Material.

Click on Save to save the chart.

 

5.3.2 Creating a Visualization for NetAmount Forecast

To visualize the forecasted NetAmount, follow the same process as before:

  1. Select the “+” tab next to the Table tab.

  2. Choose Visualization.

  3. The Visualization Editor pane will appear.

  4. Configure the parameters as follows:

Visualization Type: Line

X Column: Date

Y Column: NetAmountForecast

Y Column: NetAmountForecastMax

Y Column: NetAmountForecastMin

Group By: Material

Once applied, you should see a line chart displaying the forecasted NetAmount values, along with the maximum and minimum forecast ranges, grouped by Material.

 

 Click on Save to save the chart.

Step 6 – Generating and visualizing final results

6.1 Union Tables

In this step, we will append the rows from the df_agg and forecast_spark tables into a single table. This allows the existing values to be extended with the forecasted ones, creating a unified dataset for analysis and visualization.

Instructions:

  1. Move your mouse pointer beneath the previous section until the action line appears.

  2. Select the Assistant icon (the pink diamond).

  3. In the Assistant window, type the following instruction to generate the forecasting code:

 

Append tables df_agg and forecast_spark rows in a single table,
appending OrderQuantity values to OrderQuantityForecast values by date
and NetAmount values to NetAmountForecast values by date
keeping OrderQuantity and NetAmount values unchanged

This will generate the code required to merge the aggregated dataset (df_agg) with the forecasted dataset (forecast_spark), ensuring that both historical and predictive values are available in one consolidated table

 Click Generate and Accept.

You’ll get the following code generated:

 

from pyspark.sql import functions as F

# Add forecast columns to df_agg with nulls for forecast intervals
df_agg_ext = (
    df_agg.withColumn("OrderQuantityForecast", F.lit(None).cast("int"))
          .withColumn("NetAmountForecast", F.lit(None).cast("int"))
          .withColumn("OrderQuantityForecastMax", F.lit(None).cast("int"))
          .withColumn("OrderQuantityForecastMin", F.lit(None).cast("int"))
          .withColumn("NetAmountForecastMax", F.lit(None).cast("int"))
          .withColumn("NetAmountForecastMin", F.lit(None).cast("int"))
)

# Add actual columns to forecast_spark for union
forecast_spark_ext = (
    forecast_spark.withColumn("OrderQuantity", F.lit(None).cast("int"))
                 .withColumn("NetAmount", F.lit(None).cast("int"))
)

# Align columns for union
all_cols = [
    "Date", "salesorganization", "salesordertype", "distributionchannel",
    "organizationdivision", "soldtoparty", "salesorderitem", "material",
    "NetAmount", "NetAmountForecast", "NetAmountForecastMax", "NetAmountForecastMin",
    "OrderQuantity", "OrderQuantityForecast", "OrderQuantityForecastMax", "OrderQuantityForecastMin",
    "orderquantityunit"
]

df_union = df_agg_ext.select(all_cols).unionByName(
    forecast_spark_ext.select(all_cols), allowMissingColumns=True
)

# For each row, set OrderQuantityForecast = OrderQuantity if present, else keep forecast
# and NetAmountForecast = NetAmount if present, else keep forecast
df_union_final = (
    df_union.withColumn(
        "OrderQuantityForecast",
        F.coalesce(F.col("OrderQuantity"), F.col("OrderQuantityForecast"))
    ).withColumn(
        "NetAmountForecast",
        F.coalesce(F.col("NetAmount"), F.col("NetAmountForecast"))
    )
)

display(df_union_final)
 
Click  Run Cell to run the code.

You'll get a table with the resulting dataset

6.2 Creating a Visualization of Actual and Forecasted numbers

To better understand the results and confirm that the forecast meets expectations, you can create a visualization combining forecasted data with actual data. 

To visualize actual and forecasted OrderQuantity, follow the same process as before:

  1. Select the “+” tab next to the Table tab.

  2. Choose Visualization.

  3. The Visualization Editor pane will appear.

  4. Configure the parameters as follows:

Visualization Type: Line

Column: Date

Y Column: OrderQuantityForecast

Y Column: OrderQuantityForecastMax

Y Column: OrderQuantityForecastMin

Group By: material

Missing and NULL values: Do not display in chart

You would get the following visualization:

This visualization will display the actual values alongside the forecasted ones, including the confidence intervals (maximum and minimum). The result is a clear line chart that allows you to visually validate how well the forecast aligns with historical data.

You can then do the same with NetAmount data, selecting the following parameters values:

  • Visualization Type: Line
  • X Column: Date
  • Y Column: NetAmountForecast
  • Y Column: NetAmountForecastMax
  • Y Column: NetAmountForecastMin
  • Group By: material
  • Missing and NULL values: Do not display in chart

You would get the following visualization:

 

Step 7 - Create Product_Forecast table to save forecasted results

Now that your are satisfied with the forecasted results you would like to store them so to be able to reuse them. This can be done by materialising forecasted results as a table.

Instructions:

  1. Move your mouse pointer beneath the previous section until the action line appears.

  2. Select the Assistant icon (the pink diamond).

  3. In the Assistant window, type the following instruction to generate the forecasting code:

If doesn't exist create schema SalesOrder
then Generate a table called Product_forecast_Userxxx in SalesOrder folder from Catalog with df_union table data
When creating the forecast table, you can, of course, assign any name you prefer by specifying it directly in the Assistant window (instead of Product_forecast_Userxxx).

 You'll see next code generated:

spark.sql("CREATE SCHEMA IF NOT EXISTS SalesOrder")

df_union.write.format("delta").mode("overwrite").saveAsTable("SalesOrder.Product_forecast_Userxxx")
 

Click Run Cell to run the code.

You'll get a table created with the resulting dataset

To see the table created, click on Catalog then navigate in the tree to open the ws_it  (different name for your organization) folder and  salesorder folder

 

These results can then be used for your following analytical scenarios.

Once you get the results, you can decide to publish back the results table as a Data Product that can be visible in SAP Business Data Cloud and install it for further consumption from Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud.

For further details, you can have a look at the help on  Sharing Data Products from SAP Databricks to SAP Business Data Cloud

entry.title: Custom Situation Handling in Quality Management: Get Notified when an Inspection Lot is Created
entry.content:
Use Case: “Create Custom Situation Type for notifying users when an inspection lot is created”.

Even though standards apps are available which can be used to check the inspections lots created for the day. However, due to nature of the business role/responsibilities and frequency of inspection process, some users(customers) want the system to notify them via situation handling.

This blog is a detailed guide for configuring a custom situation type in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to notify users when an inspection lot is created. Here's a structured summary of the key concepts and steps:

Objective

Enable notifications (SAP Fiori home screen + email) when an inspection lot is created using Situation Handling – Extended Framework.

Solution Overview

  • Customizable for specific business scenarios.
  • Notifications triggered by events (e.g., inspection lot creation).
  • Delivered via SAP Fiori and email.

After setting up the custom situation type, users will be able to receive notifications on their SAP home screen and via email.

 

 

Prerequisites

Apps Required:

  • Manage Situation Objects
  • Manage Teams and Responsibilities
  • Manage Responsibility Contexts
  • Manage Situation Scenarios
  • Manage Situation Types – Extended

Roles Required:

  • BR_BUSINESS_PROCESS_SPEC
  • BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC
  • BR_ADMINISTRATOR
  • BR_BPC_EXPERT
  • BR_EMPLOYEE
  • BR_EMPLOYEE_MAINTENANC

These are default SAP roles. Custom roles depend on the authorization concept can be set-up in the specific system.

Step-by-Step Setup

Key Concept: Basic steps for creating a custom situation type in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition are outlined in the pictures below. Users can create their own situation use cases with the extended framework for Situation Handling.  The extended framework offers three new configuration apps: Mange Situation Objects, Manage Situation Scenarios, and Manage Situation Types – Extended.

The following image illustrates the activities associated with the respective applications.

 

Step 1: Create Situation Objects

With this app, users can model business objects that facilitate Situation Handling. A situation object connects existing application artifacts, such as CDS views, events, and actions, which serve as the foundation for establishing situation use cases.

Use “Manage Situation Objects” app.

  • Create object ID (Picture 1)
  • Use CDS view I_INSPECTIONLOT.
  • Define Structures: (Picture 2)
    • Set semantic keys and personal data fields. (Picture 2)
  • Define Events, anchor and trigger objects (Picture 3). In general anchor and trigger object are established on the situation scenario level. e.g. Inspection lot creation
    • In this situation, the anchor and trigger are the same, i.e. the inspection lot
  • Define navigation & actions (Picture 4 &5). The event corresponds to the modeled object created earlier and can be used as triggers.

(Picture 1)

(Picture 2)

(Picture 3)

(Picture 4)

While generic IDs like NAV01 are possible, the recommended naming would reflect the object and navigation target, e.g. YY1_NAV_MANAGE_INS_LOT.

(Picture 5)

While generic IDs like ACT1 are possible, the recommended naming would reflect the object and Action, e.g. YY1_ACT_MANAGE_INS_LOT.

For further information refer to : https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/d973eb6d464d4dce84f354b9668ef43c.html

 

Step 2: Create Responsibility Context

Manage Responsibility Contexts in SAP lets you view, use, and extend standard or custom contexts that define who is responsible for business tasks across workflows and situation handling. A responsibility context links specific business processes or objects (like inspection lot) with rules or teams to determine the responsible agents. You can extend standard contexts or create custom ones with tailored agent rules, enabling precise assignment of responsibilities to individuals or teams for better workflow and process management.

A team is defined in the app ‘Manage Teams and Responsibilities’ whereas Team category is assigned in the app ’Manage Responsibility Context’. Using configuration ‘Define Team Types’ the mapping of team type and team category is done.

  • Create team in “Manage Teams and Responsibilities”.
  • Define context in “Manage Responsibility Contexts”.(Picture 7 &'8)
    • Add team category. (Picture 6 &'8)

(Picture 6 – Concept)

(Picture 7)

(Picture '8)

For further information refer to the blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/responsibility-management-what-is-it-and-why-do-you-need-it-1-5/ba-p/13713337

 

Step 3: Create Situation Scenario

This app helps to create your own scenarios for extended object-based situations. These are situations that occur for a specific business object, like an inspection lot. A situation scenario is a technical description of a business scenario and serves as the foundation for defining multiple use cases in the form of situation templates. 

A situation scenario consists of one anchor object and one/more trigger objects. An anchor object is the object that is affected by a situation, such as an inspection lot. A trigger object creates an impact that results in situation instances for the anchor object, such as creation of an inspection lot.

Use “Manage Situation Scenarios”.

  • Define scenario ID, type (Object-based), and structure (CDS). (Picture 9)
  • Select the anchor object and anchor object structure (Picture 9)
  • Add the instance key, i.e. the anchor object. (Picture 10)
  • Define List page layout (Picture 10).
  • Define general and specific actions. (Picture 11)
  • Define parameters for situation triggers (Picture 12 & 13) – It can be triggered via events (e.g when inspection lot is created) or using batch jobs (e.g. running batch jobs every few hours to notify users on the created inspection lots)
  • Define Situation Page (Picture 13A) - Here user can select the field which should be populated in the notification details.

(Picture 9)

(Picture 10)

(Picture 11)

(Picture 12)

(Picture 13)

(Picture 13A)

For further information refer to: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/dfac958be2af4ce79589e8a3eaff88d6.html

 

Step 4: Create Team

This app allows users to manage teams, define responsibilities, and assign functions to team members in the Responsibility Management section. By using responsibility definitions and member functions, you can identify the members (recipients) who are responsible for workflows, business scenarios, and handling situations.

Use “Manage Teams and Responsibility”.

  • Assign team type. The category will be automatically filled. (Picture 14)
  • Responsibility parameters will be populated automatically based on the configuration ‘Assign Custom Responsibility Definition’ SSCUI- 102159 (e.g., plant)
  • Assign member functions for notification routing. The members are also not only for receiving notifications, but also for those who gets to see situations/situation instances in the app ‘My Situations – Extended’

(Picture 14)

For further information refer to: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/73c04858392e9244e10000000a4450e5.html

 

Step 5: Create Situation Template

Situation templates are used to define and standardize the monitoring of specific business exceptions or critical situations. These templates act as blueprints for different situation types.

Use “Manage Situation Types – Extended”.

  • Define template ID, scenario, and triggers. (Picture 15)
  • Choose if user needs the instances to be kept (Picture 16)
  • Set General Actions (Picture 17)
  • Define situation Triggers (Picture 18)
    • Set conditions and filters. (Picture 19, 20) e.g. Inspection type
    • Configure display and notification texts. (Picture 21)
    • Optional: define navigation actions. (Picture 22)

(Picture 15)

(Picture – 16)

(Picture – 17)

(Picture – 18)

(Picture – 19)

(Picture – 20)

(Picture 21)

(Picture – 22)

For further information refer to:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/45d60edcf02d409c87076f9270372eb8.html

 

Step 6: Create Situation Type

Situation types describe a business situation that defines how a situation instance is triggered and who is informed about it. In the extended framework for Situation Handling, the configuration of a situation type also includes the definition of actions for solving a situation. These situations are automatically detected and addressed by identifying and handling critical events or exceptions within business processes. Situation types are derived from templates and offer customization options for conditions, notifications, responsible users, and informative texts for users. Upon activation, they generate situation instances that promptly notify the designated users, thereby enhancing process efficiency and decision-making.

Use “Manage Situation Types – Extended”.

  • Create situation type by copying the template created in the previous step.
  • Enable status. (Picture 23)
  • Triggers, actions, and recipients (processors) are copied from the template. For batch trigger a recurrence must be defined here. (Picture 24)
  • Use Teams or rules for processor assignment.

(Picture 23)

(Picture – 24)

Here is an overview of the modelled custom situation template & type for this use case

(Picture – 25)

Our recommendation is to not create IDs with spaces, so the ID would better be YY1_INSPECTION_LOT_CREATED

For further information refer to:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/45d60edcf02d409c87076f9270372eb8.html

 

Step 7: Test

  • Create inspection lot manually or via goods receipt.
  • Check notifications
    • in home screen (Picture 26, 28)
    • bell icon (Picture 27, 28)
    • Email (if Email notification is enabled in the user settings) (Picture 29)
    • “My Situations – Extended” app (Picture 30)

(Picture 26)

 

(Picture 27)

 If users navigate from the notification

 

(Picture 28)

  • Description (comes from situation type)
  • Usage decision information (comes from situation scenario > situation page layout)
  • Related apps (button comes from defined actions from situation objects, detailed in situation scenario, situation template and type) 

(Picture 29)

 

(Picture 30)

 In each step only necessary information has been provided without over describing it. But to further help the readers we have provided all the necessary SAP Help links to set up their own situation handling scenario easily. 

Hope you will be able to set up your own custom situation.

entry.title: Re: HXEDownloadManager can't run on windows 10
entry.content:
On my company laptop both: java -jar HXEDownloadManager.jar -h and HXEDownloadManager_win.exe (downloaded today) fail. The Java version running in Cmd.exe fails with the message:
Cannot open log file C:\Users\ROMANS~1\AppData\Local\Temp\\hxedm251126.log.

Both programs work on my private minicomputer, the difference seems to be that on the minicomputer my username (per Whoami) is just "nuc\roman" and not "azuread\romanstangl". The log file mentions hints to me that this is a filename mangling problem where NTFS directory names are converted to FAT 8.3 compatibility (the ~ was typical for that 20+ years ago, no idea why that hack is still surfacing ;-)).

The fix is to change the TMP environment variable from TMP=C:\Users\ROMANS~1\AppData\Local\Temp to e.g. TMP=D:\Temp (or even TMP=C:\Users\RomanStangl\AppData\Local\Temp).
Looks like that even Windows 11 still applies that filename mangling to the paths set in the TEMP and TMP environment variables, really astonishing.

entry.title: YTD Calculation in Restricted/Calculated Measure with 200 Dimensions in SAP DataSphere
entry.content:
Context and Goal

We are building an Analytic Model in SAP Datasphere, based on a view with approximately 200 columns/dimensions. Our goal is to calculate the Year-to-Date (YTD) value for the measure "SalesAmount". The YTD calculation must be dynamic, allowing the end-user to analyze the result by Year, Month, and any of the ~198 remaining dimensions in the model (example: Customer, Product, Region, etc.).

Attempted Solutions and Specific Issue
 We have tried to implement the YTD calculation directly within the Analytic Model, following SAP documentation:

1. Restricted Measure Attempt: 

     Expression: We defined a restricted measure for "SalesAmount" with the following filter condition on the date dimension ("SalesDate"):  SalesDate IN (YTD(SalesDate))

     Result: The model fails to activate. Upon deployment, Datasphere throws the following syntax error:

           Reason: Invalid syntax or usage of unsupported function. unexpected character: ->Y<- at offset: 0, skipped 3 characters.

Observation: The YTD() function does not seem to be recognized or supported in this context/syntax, despite being suggested by the expression editor.

2. Calculated Measure Attempt:

  • Expression: We also tried creating a calculated measure using the YTD() function:  YTD(SalesAmount, SalesDate)

  • Result: The outcome is the same; the model fails to activate and shows the identical syntax error related to the 'Y' character.

3. SQL View Implementation (Window Function):

  • Approach: We tried calculating the running total using the OVER (PARTITION BY Year ORDER BY Month) window function within the source view (View Builder).

  • Limitation: This approach is unworkable because it limits the drill-down capability. The calculation is performed only at the Year/Month level, and since it is a calculated column in the view, we cannot dynamically disaggregate the YTD by the other ~198 dimensions in the model (e.g., if we filter by a specific "Customer", the calculated YTD would still be the total across all customers up to that "Month").

4. SAC (SAP Analytics Cloud) - Import Model Test:

  • Approach: We created an Import Model in SAC, and there, the YTD() function (implemented as a calculated account) works perfectly and allows for dynamic drill-down across all dimensions.

  • Limitation: This forces us to lose the Real-Time capability of SAP Datasphere and the Live Connection, which is an unacceptable trade-off for our use case.

Question to the Community

Is there an alternative, supported syntax or method in SAP Datasphere, within the Analytic Consumption Model (or a dynamically aggregate-aware View Builder approach) to calculate YTD while respecting all dimensions in the model?

Any workaround or confirmation on whether the YTD() function in Restricted or Calculated Measures is actually supported in the current version of Datasphere would be highly appreciated.

Thank you in advance for your assistance!

entry.title: Re: Material Management - Release Strategy
entry.content:
Hi @Eddie88 ,
Correct, you should review and adjust the “Chgable” (changeable) settings in your release strategy configuration. The “Delivery Complete” (ELIKZ) flag is technically treated as a change to the PO item, and if your release strategy is configured to re-trigger on any change, it will cause a new release cycle. Best practice is to mark statistical or non-commercial fields (like ELIKZ) as non-change relevant so they don’t reset the release strategy

I would like to recommend you these adjustments.
1. Check release strategy configuration (SPRO path)
Materials Management → Purchasing → Purchase Order → Release Procedure. Review the Changeability Indicator for your release strategy.

2. Set “Chgable” appropriately
Use option 2 (Changeable, new release in case of changes) only for commercial/critical fields (price, quantity, vendor). For statistical fields like ELIKZ, set 4 (Changeable, no new release in case of changes) so updates don’t trigger a new release.

3. Test in QA first
Perform a mass update of ELIKZ in your test system. Confirm that the release strategy remains stable and does not reset.

4. Alternative approach:
If business policy requires strict control, you can exclude ELIKZ from mass updates and instead automate its setting via GR/IR processes (SAP Note 1093582 explains how ELIKZ can be auto-set during goods receipt or invoice posting)

The Best Practice is as mentioned below.
Differentiate between commercial vs. statistical changes: Only commercial changes should re-trigger release. Automate ELIKZ where possible, Configure tolerance ranges so the system sets “Delivery Complete” automatically after final GR. Communicate with stakeholders and Ensure procurement and finance teams agree on which fields should be release-relevant.

Hope my suggestion is fine with you.

Answer to question 1: Yes, it is because C007 orders have no header material, therefore there is nothing to deliver. Delivery logic only exists for production orders you create with a material. In your case the open quantity will remain 1 PC and will not affect your costing, stock or accounting.

Answer to point 2: See answer 1.

Answer to question 3: Yes, it is. All GR postings are automatically non-valuated, only the component consumptions posts to FI. That is the expected journal entry for disassembly. In your case nothing has been consumed and hence why no change in quantity.

entry.title: Subscription Management for Software (5SW)
entry.content:
In today’s software-driven business environment, subscription-based models are increasingly the norm. Managing subscriptions, entitlements, usage, billing  and revenue recognition can become complex without a robust system in place. SAP addresses this challenge with an integrated end-to-end process across SAP Cloud ERP, SAP Subscription Billing, and SAP Entitlement Management. This solution simplifies subscription management while enabling automation and comprehensive insights into software usage and revenue.

With 2508 release SAP has provided an end-2-end Best Practice content for Software and SaaS use cases. The goal of this Best Practice is to significantly reduce time-to-value by providing clear setup instructions for common processes along the end-2-end value chain. The Best Practice content is provided via the new scope item 5SW (link to scope item in the Process Navigator).

 

What does Scope Item 5SW cover?

This scope item enables a seamless process for the full lifecycle of software subscriptions. From subscription modeling and pricing to fulfillment, billing, and revenue recognition, the integration ensures all steps are connected:

  • Subscription Modeling & Pricing: Define software subscription products, base and add-on licenses, and pricing models.
  • Sales & Fulfillment: Sell subscriptions through solution orders in SAP Cloud ERP and manage provisioning in SAP Entitlement Management.
  • License & Usage Management: Track entitlements, license consumption, and software usage to ensure compliance and optimize revenue.
  • Billing & Revenue Recognition: Automate billing for recurring, one-time, and usage-based charges, and ensure accurate revenue recognition.
  • End-of-Life Processes: Decommission licenses and tenants at the end of subscription contracts efficiently.

This scope item consolidates several existing capabilities, including Subscription Management with Sales Billing, corresponding capabilities of Solution Order Management, and Event-Based Revenue Recognition, Subscription Billing, extended with SAP Entitlement Management functionalities.

Key Process Flow

Process Flow

  1. Creation or Update of the Solution Order
    The Solution Order Specialist initiates the process by creating a new Solution Order or updating an existing one. This serves as the foundation for all subsequent subscription and billing activities.
  2. Automatic Subscription Creation in SAP Subscription Billing
    If the Solution Order includes a subscription item, a corresponding subscription is automatically created in SAP Subscription Billing with a pending status. This ensures that the subscription lifecycle is immediately tracked and initialized.
  3. Entitlement Assignment and Provisioning
    In SAP Entitlement Management, entitlements can be added to the subscription to define the customer’s access rights. Once entitlements are assigned, tenant and license provisioning are triggered to enable the actual usage.
  4. Subscription Finalization and Activation
    After entitlement configuration and provisioning, the subscription is finalized and activated. This marks the transition from setup to operational use.
  5. Automatic Creation of Provider Contract and Billing Plan
    With the subscription activated, SAP Cloud ERP automatically generates the Provider Contract and the associated billing plan. These define the contractual framework and scheduling for invoicing.
  6. Revenue Recognition
    Based on the activated subscription and billing data, Revenue Recognition can be monitored in the SAP Cloud ERP system.

 

  1. Detection of Billing Cycle End
    Once the end of the billing cycle is detected, the process for capturing license usage begins. In SAP Entitlement Management, both software consumption and actual license utilization are recorded.
  2. Transfer and Rating of Usage Data
    The recorded usage data is automatically sent to SAP Subscription Billing. There, it is rated according to the predefined price models and tariff rules.
  3. Automatic Billing in SAP Subscription Billing
    Based on the consumed quantity and the billing cycle, SAP Subscription Billing automatically generates bills. This eliminates manual effort and ensures consistent and rule-based billing.
  4. Creation of Billing Document Request (BDR)
    The generated bills are transferred to SAP Cloud ERP, where a Billing Document Request (BDR) is created. This serves as the foundation for further processing in the ERP system.
  5. Generation of Billing Documents
    Using the BDR, the final Billing Documents are created in SAP Cloud ERP. They contain all relevant billing information and can be used for financial posting and customer communication.
  6. Event-Based Revenue Recognition
    Finally, event-based Revenue Recognition is executed. This ensures that revenue is posted in compliance with accounting standards, enabling accurate financial reporting.

  1. Decommissioning of Tenants and Licenses
    Once the subscription contract reaches its end, the associated tenants and licenses can be properly decommissioned. This ensures that access is revoked, resources are released, and the offboarding process is completed in a controlled manner.

 

Business Benefits

Implementing this integrated scope item delivers significant advantages:

  • End-to-End Automation: Streamline modelling, selling, fulfillment, and billing of software subscriptions.
  • Flexible License Management: Use generic license templates for multiple applications, tenant types, and metrics.
  • Efficient Provisioning & Updates: Automate updates, add-ons, and decommissioning of licenses and tenants.
  • Usage Insights: Monitor adoption, detect low, and prevent revenue leakage from overuse.
  • Flexible Billing Models: Support recurring, one-time, and usage-based billing.
  • Integrated Revenue Recognition: Ensure compliance and accuracy in multi-license scenarios.

Conclusion

By combining SAP Cloud ERP, SAP Subscription Billing, and SAP Entitlement Management, businesses can achieve a fully integrated, automated subscription management process to explicitly cover common requirements of software & SaaS use cases. This approach not only reduces operational complexity but also enhances visibility into software usage, adoption, and revenue—empowering companies to maximize value from their subscription offerings.

entry.title: Re: What Tax Group should be tagged when purchasing to a...
entry.content:
Hi @Ivan123,
When purchasing from an international supplier in SAP, you typically tag the transaction with an Input Tax Group (A/P tax group) that reflects Import/Zero-rated VAT or a custom tax code configured for imports. The exact tax group depends on your country’s tax regulations (e.g., “Import VAT,” “No Tax,” or “Reverse Charge”) and how your SAP system is localized.

Which country are you operating in?
For example:
In Saudi Arabia, imports are subject to VAT at customs, so you’d use an “Import VAT” tax group.
In the EU, you’d often apply a “Reverse Charge” tax code for intra-EU suppliers.
In the US, many companies tag international purchases as “No Tax” but may apply use tax later.
Once I know your country, I can give you the exact SAP tax group setup that fits your local compliance requirements.
